com.teamwork.autocomplete.filter

Interface TokenFilter<M>

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BaseTokenFilter, HandleTokenFilter, SimpleTokenFilter

    public interface TokenFilter<M>
    Interface for components that implement the filtering feature of AutoCompleteTypeAdapters.

    Includes methods to detect if a token is supported, filter a list of items coming from the type adapter and provide a Comparator to sort the results.

    Implementations should be thread safe.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ConstraintComparator<M> getConstraintComparator()
      Return an optional ConstraintComparator to sort the filtered items based on the current text constraint.

    • Method Detail

      • supportsToken

        boolean supportsToken(@NonNull
                      java.lang.CharSequence token)
        Check whether the provided token is supported by the filter. When true is returned, the TokenFilter can perform filtering and recognize the items that are valid for the other auto completion features.
        Parameters:
        token - The token string.
        Returns:
        true if the token text is supported, false otherwise.

      • stripHandle

        @NonNull
java.lang.CharSequence stripHandle(@NonNull
                                            java.lang.CharSequence token)
        Remove the token handle from the passed token if present.
        Parameters:
        token - The token string to remove the handle from.
        Returns:
        The token without the handle if found.

      • toTokenString

        @NonNull
java.lang.CharSequence toTokenString(@NonNull
                                              M item)
        Return the token string representation of the passed item. Note that this could be different from the #toString() representation, for example to add a handle when supported.

        This is used by the Filter.convertResultToString(Object) method for user suggestions and auto complete and by the AutoCompleteTypeAdapter to match token strings with the user-typed characters.

        Parameters:
        item - The item whose token string representation is needed.
        Returns:
        The token string.

      • getValidTokenPattern

        @Nullable
java.util.regex.Pattern getValidTokenPattern()
        Return an optional "valid token" pattern that matches full tokens which can be associated with the items data. This can be used by the AutoCompleteTypeAdapter to detect tokens and notify when a token is added/removed by the user in the auto complete edit text view.

        For performance reasons, the same instance of Pattern should be returned at every method call.

        Returns:
        The "valid token" pattern for this filter.

      • performFiltering

        @WorkerThread
 @NonNull
java.util.List<M> performFiltering(@NonNull
                                                           java.lang.CharSequence constraint,
                                                           @NonNull
                                                           java.util.List<M> items)
        Perform the actual items filtering, delegating to the filter the decision whether each items matches the passed text constraint.

        This method must always be executed from a worker thread.

        Parameters:
        constraint - The current text constraint to be used for matching.
        items - The list of items to iterate and filter (the list shouldn't be modified by implementations).
        Returns:
        A new List containing the items that have matched the constraint.

      • getConstraintComparator

        @WorkerThread
 @Nullable
ConstraintComparator<M> getConstraintComparator()
        Return an optional ConstraintComparator to sort the filtered items based on the current text constraint.

        Note that it's more efficient, performance-wise, to just sort the initial list set and then pass it to AutoCompleteTypeAdapter.setItems(List) and return null from this method, if the ordering never depends on the text constraint.

        Returns:
        The ConstraintComparator instance, can be reused across calls if possible, or null if the filtered results can use the original items list order.
